May just be me. I can be quite anal.

@love Mm didn’t think about that. Doesn’t matter too much, although I might just change it.

item.title: Adding sub classes to an array from a particular super class
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

lemme_winks_:

why the hell aren’t you using a dynamic array/container–that wouldn’t even work

I believe I am for the stock?

Also, I decided I am going to do it this way. “What I am going to do is just load the shops from XML and do it that way instead. Still use my superclass though. Then I could load them into an ArrayList and iterate through that instead.”

package org.apollo.game.model.inter.shop;

import org.apollo.game.model.Inventory;
import org.apollo.game.model.Item;

/**
 * Shop.java
 * @author The Wanderer
 */
public abstract class Shop {
    
    public static final int PLAYER_INVENTORY_INTERFACE = 3823;
    
    public static final int SHOP_INVENTORY_INTERFACE = 3900;
    
    public static final int SIZE = 40;

    public abstract Item[] getDefaultStock();
    
    public abstract String getName();

    public abstract boolean isGeneralStore();

    public abstract int getCurrency();
    
    public abstract void populateShop();
    
    public abstract Inventory getStock();
}

[code=Java]package org.apollo.game.model.inter.shop.impl;

import org.apollo.game.model.Inventory;
import org.apollo.game.model.Item;
import org.apollo.game.model.inter.shop.Shop;

/**
*

  • @author The Wanderer
    */
    public class AlKharidGeneralStore extends Shop {

    public Item[] DefaultStock = {new Item(1931, 3), new Item(1935, 2), new Item(5603, 2), new Item(1925, 2), new Item(590, 2), new Item(1755, 2), new Item(2347, 5)};
    public static final Inventory stock = new Inventory(Shop.SIZE, Inventory.StackMode.STACK_ALWAYS);

    @Override
    public Item[] getDefaultStock() {
    return DefaultStock;
    }

    @Override
    public void populateShop() {
    Item[] defaultStock = getDefaultStock();
    for (int k = 0; k < defaultStock.length; k++) {
    stock.add(defaultStock[k]);
    }
    }

    @Override
    public String getName() {
    return “Al Kharid General Store”;
    }

    @Override
    public boolean isGeneralStore() {
    return true;
    }

    @Override
    public int getCurrency() {
    return 995;
    }

    @Override
    public Inventory getStock() {
    return stock;
    }
    }[/code]

Read full topic

Shop alk = new AlKharidGeneralStore();
alk.populateShop();

That would be worse?

What I am going to do is just load the shops from XML and do it that way instead. Still use my superclass though. Then I could load them into an ArrayList and iterate through that instead.
[/quote]

least i didnt store it into a array[/quote]

item.title: Adding sub classes to an array from a particular super class
item.dc:creator: @Pure_Slay Pure Slay
item.description:
@Pure_Slay wrote:

public void populateShop(Item[] storeStock) {
for(int i = 0; i < storeStock.length; i++) {
stock.add(storeStoke[i]);
}

free hand, you can just call that method in the constructor with the array being your items declared in that extending shop class.

item.source: Adding sub classes to an array from a particular super class

item.title: Adding sub classes to an array from a particular super class
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

Ah that might not work, because you can’t have an abstract variable. Like I’ll show you.

[code=Java]
public Item[] DefaultStock = {new Item(1931, 3), new Item(1935, 2), new Item(5603, 2), new Item(1925, 2), new Item(590, 2), new Item(1755, 2), new Item(2347, 5)};

@Override
public Item[] getDefaultStock() {
    return DefaultStock;
}

@Override
public void populateShop() {
    Item[] defaultStock = getDefaultStock();
    for (int k = 0; k < defaultStock.length; k++) {
        stock.add(defaultStock[k]);
    }
}[/code]

Read full topic
item.source: Adding sub classes to an array from a particular super class

item.title: Adding sub classes to an array from a particular super class
item.dc:creator: @Pure_Slay Pure Slay
item.description:
@Pure_Slay wrote:

[quote=“The Wanderer, post:8, topic:429547”][quote author=Pure Slay link=topic=532238.msg3890241#msg3890241 date=1326773946]
Add the populating method in the super class, and call it in the constructor of the class extending.
[/quote]
Ohoh. That’s a smart way of doing it. <3 What if the populating method is different for each subclass is different (although I don’t think they are)?[/quote]

Populating is most likely based on the size of the array/map/ect for the extending shop class, right? So as long as you are leaving the super class method abstract to the size of the extending class, their really shouldn’t be problems. I doubt you would need that approach anyways.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

Why are you having an integer parameter for shopName?

And super was saying I should do this I think

[code=Java]Shop alk = new AlKharidGeneralStore();
Shop rune = new AuburyRuneStore();
Shop lumby = new LumbyGeneralStore();

alk.populateShop();
rune.populateShop();
lumby.populateShop();
[/code]
Which would be worse. I may be misunderstanding him.

Also how can you construct a new shopName when shopName isn’t a object? [/code]

[/quote]

supermans wouldn’t be worse from what I know,
what would be worse is what I thought about lol
like making a void from it to shorten it

public static void Shop (int shopName) {
 shopName alk = new shopName();
                Shop[] shops = {alk};
                for(int i = 0; i < shops.length; i++) {
                    shops[i].populateShop();
                }
Class.Shop(AlKahridGeneralStore);

item.source: Adding sub classes to an array from a particular super class

item.title: Adding sub classes to an array from a particular super class
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

Alright I have a abstract class named Shop and I have a abstract method in there called populateShop. What I want to do is for every class that extends Shop to run that method. The only way I thought of doing that is make and array of Shop like…

AlKharidGeneralStore alk = new AlKharidGeneralStore(); Shop[] shops = {alk}; for(int i = 0; i < shops.length; i++) { shops[i].populateShop(); }
Now as you can see that is very tedious and would take a lot of room if I had a lot of shops. Is there a better way to do this?

Read full topic
